Analysis of studies shows that non-pharmacological methods used to control pain in neonates are much more effective when used in combination with other non-pharmacological methods, such as music therapy, swaddling, facilitated tucking, multiple-stimulation, kangaroo care and non-nutritive suction.

questions.body: What is synthetic lethality?

snippets.text: Exploiting a phenomenon known as synthetic lethality, in which simultaneous loss of two interacting genes leads to loss of viability, aids in the investigation of these interactions.
One such genetic interaction is synthetic lethality, in which the combination of two non-lethal mutations leads to loss of organism viability.
Synthetic lethality is the synthesis of mutations leading to cell death. Tumor-specific synthetic lethality has been targeted in research to improve c
ment of novel anticancer therapies. SL can be described as lethality (cell death) resulting from the combination of the two mutations, wherein the mut
Synthetic lethality occurs when inhibition or mutation in two or more separate genes leads to cell death while inhibition or mutations of either gene alone has no lethal effect on the cell.
Synthetic lethality is a promising strategy for specific targeting of cancer cells that carry mutations that are absent in normal cells.
Inhibition of PARP in DNA repair-defective tumors (like those with BRAC1/2 mutations) can lead to cell death and genomic instability, what is so called "synthetic lethality".
Synthetic lethality exploits cancer cell dependency on a protein or pathway, which arises when the function of a tumor suppressor is defective.

BACKGROUND
Synthetic lethality defines a genetic interaction where the combination of mutations in two or more genes leads to cell death.
Synthetic lethality is based on the incompatibility of cell survival with the loss of function of two or more genes, not with loss of function of a single gene.

Optogenetics refers to the ability to control cells that have been genetically modified to express light-sensitive ion channels.
Optogenetics refers to the genetic modification of cells to express light-sensitive proteins, which mediate ion flow or secondary signalling cascades upon light exposure.
Optogenetics refers to the control of biological processes with light. The activation of cellular phenomena by defined wavelengths has several advanta
ly understood as the manipulation of the activity of genetically modified cells (typically neurons) with light, i.e. optical actuators. (2) A second c

precision. However, outside of neuroscience, the impact of optogenetics has been limited by a lack of user-friendly, flexible, accessible hardware. Here, we engineer the Light Plate Apparatus (LPA), a device that can deliver two independent 310 to 1550 nm light signals to each well of a 24-well plate with intensity control over three orders of magnitude and millisecond resolution. Signals are programmed using an intuitive web tool named Iris. All components can be purchased for under $400 and the device can be assembled and calibrated by a non-expert in one day. We use the LPA to precisely control gene expression from blue, green, and red light responsive optogenetic tools in bacteria, yeast, and mammalian cells
Optogenetics is the use of genetically coded, light-gated ion channels or pumps (opsins) for millisecond resolution control of neural activity.

However, unlike gene therapy, which is aimed at repairing damaged genes or replacing them with healthy ones, optogenetics is focused on protein genes delivery for further molecular control of the cell.

OBJECTIVE
This paper aims to describe the clinical and regulatory aspects of new drugs and indications that were approved for lung, breast, prostate, and colorectal cancer, from 2016 to 2018, in order to provide health technology assessment trends in oncology.

PD-1 inhibitor Keytruda combined with chemotherapy for Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has been approved for FDA, successfully representing the combination therapy of immunotherapy and chemotherapy for the first time in 2020.
The FDA has approved ribociclib combined with aromatase inhibitor therapy for women with metastatic HR-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer.

Pembrolizumab (Keytruda) is now approved as a single agent to treat advanced endometrial carcinoma that is microsatellite instability-high or mismatch repair deficient in those whose disease has progressed following prior systemic therapy in any setting and who are not candidates for curative surgery or radiation.

questions.body: Was DNX-2401 tested for treatment of Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma?

snippets.text:
BACKGROUND
There are no effective treatments for diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas (DIPGs); these tumors cannot be surgical resected, and diagnosis is based on magnetic resonance imaging.
Although large numbers of specific targeted therapies have been tested, no significant progress has been made in treating these high-grade gliomas.
Clinical trials evaluating intratumoral DNX-2401 in adults with recurrent glioblastoma have demonstrated that the virus has a favorable safety profile and can prolong survival.

BACKGROUND
No link has been demonstrated between diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma and developmental venous anomaly in pediatric patients.
Methods A phase I, dose-escalation, biologic-end-point clinical trial of DNX-2401 was conducted in 37 patients with recurrent malignant glioma.
Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) is a lethal pediatric tumor with no currently available treatment options.

Conclusion Treatment with DNX-2401 resulted in dramatic responses with long-term survival in recurrent high-grade gliomas that are probably due to direct oncolytic effects of the virus followed by elicitation of an immune-mediated antiglioma response.
Diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas (DIPGs) are invariably fatal tumors found in the pons of elementary school aged children.
In diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma compared to low-grade brainstem glioma, axial diffusivity was lower in the bilateral posterior limb of the internal capsule.

BACKGROUND
The standard treatment for diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) is radiotherapy, although conventional fractionated radiotherapy (CFRT) may not be in the best interest of the patient.
